children.subject: We can explore doing this approach on exam 3.  Let's discuss again closer to...
One aspect that I think no matter how good your handwriting, is far clearer in print: distinguish $$V$$ from $$\vee$$, $$v$$ from $$\nu$$

Yep, as hard as I try (maybe too hard), I could hardly tell the difference in my own handwriting for these letters.  Sometimes I tried to correct it to make it more clear, but always ends up looking worse:).  So in that regard, I am grateful the TAs decoded my scribbles with little complaints (or I just did not hear about it).

I am not complaining, but I am blaming the deficiency in my handwriting for some of the obvious mistakes I made in the exams because I never had so many "what in the world was I thinking" moments in one course.  Practice makes it better, and I am hopeful I will  get the hang of it before final exam.

Personally I find the Latex code is easier to manager than unicode, but typing in any code is easier than handwriting for me.  Actually it's not hard for me to write with my hand---I still do it all the time, but there has been so many complaints for years from those who had to read my handwriting that I have been relying on typing (in code or else) to share my ideas for a while:).  This course is the first time in a long time that someone actually has to read my handwriting:).

Not sure we will make it in this session or exam, but if it's open for change, I think Google Doc (Insert->) Equation is the most useful and easiest to use among different paths I attempted---again I would go the length to save people from having to read my handwriting.  I do not need to remember any code (unicode or Latex) with Goodle Doc, for what we use in this class anyway, and it's in the cloud.

history.content:
Hello All,

I said I would document how it would be possible to potentially type this stuff up in Word, and I wanted to document the characters I use here - so this post is a reference when typing in Word (maybe one can be started for other word processors).  To get these special characters, you type out the 4-digit hex number and then immediately press Alt+x in Word.  The list (full list available here):

DescCharacterCode
Subset⊂2282
Not Equals≠2260
Exists∈2208
Does Not Exist∉2209
Arrow→2192
Left-Right Double Arrow⇔21d4
For All∀2200

Thanks,

Brent
history.subject: Useful Word Character Reference

history.content:
Hello All,

I said I would document how it would be possible to potentially type this stuff up in Word, and I wanted to document the characters I use here - so this post is a reference when typing in Word (maybe one can be started for other word processors).  To get these special characters, you type out the 4-digit hex number and then immediately press Alt+x in Word.  The list (full list available here):

Subset                               ⊂        2282

Not Equals                          ≠        2260

Exists                                  ∈        2208

Does Not Exist                    ∉         2209

Arrow                                  →        2192

Left-Right Double Arrow     ⇔         21d4

For All  \t                              ∀         2200

Thanks,

Brent
